title: Steph McGovern quits BBC Breakfast to host her own Channel 4 show
text:

BBC Breakfast presenter Steph McGovern has quit BBC Breakfast in order to land her own show on Channel 4.

The heavily pregnant host, who presents the business briefing segments of the show every weekday from 6-9.15am, will now be fronting the Channel 4 programme The Steph Show from spring 2020.

"I'm really chuffed to be creating my own live show," she said.

"This is a dream come true for me and I can't wait to get started next year. Just a small matter of having a baby first!"

(Image: WireImage)

A BBC insider told Mirror Online that Steph didn't want to continue with her gruelling early-morning shifts after she gives birth next month.

"She is definitely leaving Breakfast but won't be exclusively signed to Channel 4," they went on.

"It means she'll be able to continue working with the BBC on shows like Watchdog."

In a statement, Channel 4 said: "The new programme will be a mix of entertainment, lifestyle and light current affairs as Steph meets a variety of guests from the worlds of showbiz, politics and beyond.

"Steph will be joined by a different, well-known co-host each week for a lively look at the topics of the day, as well as consumer affairs, fun features and lots of interaction with the viewers - all filmed in front of a live audience."

The Steph Show will be broadcast live from Leeds, the home of Channel 4's new national HQ.

(Image: BBC)

Her Breakfast colleague Dan Walker confirmed she's leaving their early daytime show, tweeting: "She will be a big loss but she'll also be fantastic at her new gig and we wish her all the best.

"Well done @stephbreakfast (I imagine you'll have to change that now) Consistently brilliant."

Gavin Allen, head of BBC News Output, said: "We are sad to see Steph leave the BBC Breakfast sofa and I know she will be missed by her colleagues and the team in Salford.

"Steph is a terrific broadcaster and we wish her the very best with her new arrival and future show."

Steph, 37, has worked on Breakfast since 2011.

She started her career by doing work experience on the BBC's Tomorrow's World, then landed a producing job for Radio 4's Today programme.

(Image: BBC)

She recently hit headlines for her brutal takedown of Boris Johnson over his sexist remarks.

She upbraided the PM for branding David Cameron a "girly swot" after he was quizzed at an event in Rotherham.

The presenter - who was not representing the BBC at the event - said just after Mr Johnson left the stage: "I'd just like to point out I am a girly swot, and I'm proud of it!

"Let's see who's in the job for longest."

As the crowd at the Convention of the North laughed, she moved swiftly on with the agenda saying: "Right... so..."

(Image: BBC)

The star later tweeted: "At a non BBC event I was hosting today, I made a light hearted remark after the Prime Minister’s speech. Sorry that this caused offence to some. That was absolutely not my intention."

The beloved presenter spoke back in 2016 about her "eye-opening" paychecks, revealing: "Since becoming a BBC Breakfast presenter I have been paid four-figure sums for doing hour-long speeches for associations and at awards dinners.

"That has been an eye-opener. I am surprised by how much people are willing to pay TV celebrities to do that kind of stuff."

She had said her best financial year was 2015 - but not because of her yearly salary.

(Image: Anthony Higham)

"Not because of my BBC salary - that has not changed for several years - but because of all the extra shows I have been doing and the speeches," she recalled

"I spent some of the money I made on a holiday to Cuba and used some of it to pay my tax bill early.

"I am so paranoid - I had already pretty much paid my 2015-16 tax bill even before the tax year had ended."

Steph has also presented Shop Well For Less and Watchdog during her time at the BBC.
description: Pregnant BBC Breakfast presenter Steph McGovern has jumped ship to Channel 4 to host a daily live show
